Rationale  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been the major partner 
of the  Government of  Mongolia in reforming the health sector 
through the Health Sector Development Program (HSDP). Over 
the last 5 years, the Government and Ministry of Health  (MOH) 
have made great progress in replacing the inefficient hospital-
based  system,  which  is  biased  toward  curative  care,  with  a 
system  based  on  primary  health  care  (PHC)  and  preventive 
services. In particular, the concept of family medicine has been 
introduced  and  a  network  of  family  group  practices  (FGPs) 
established. However, much remains to be done to embed the 
changes and deepen their impact; further efforts to improve the 
quality of FGPs and rationalize hospital facilities and overstaffing 
are essential.  
 
ADB will continue its partnership with the Government in helping 
(i) improve rural health service delivery, especially  to  achieve 
Millennium Development Goals  at all levels of the rural health 
system;  (ii)  introduce  changes  in  traditional  popular  views  of 
health  services;  (iii)  strengthen  the  reform  process  and  MOH 
capacity to implement reforms; and (iv) study and test initiatives of 
public sector management and health care financing mechanisms 
to improve sector efficiency, sustainability, and pro-poor focus. 
 
Objectives and Scope  The  goal  of  the  Second  Health  Sector  Development  Project 
(HSDP2) is to  improve the health of  the people, especially the 
poor and vulnerable, including women and  children, in targeted 
rural areas. HSDP2 has two objectives: (i) improve the quality and 
utilization of health services in rural areas, especially for the poor 
and vulnerable; and (ii)  build the capacity of the health sector, 
extending  the  reforms  in  sector  efficiency,  effectiveness,  and 
sustainability, and institutional development initiated by the HSDP.

  HSDP2 has three components: (i) integrated improvement of rural 
health services, (ii)  institutional capacity  development, and  (iii) 
project management. Component (i) will be  implemented in  five

Hentiy), which were selected for their level and severity of poverty, 
levels of infant and maternal mortality, and incidence of infectious 
diseases. Components (ii) and (iii) are nationwide. HSDP2 will 
focus investment in areas that will have the greatest impact on the 
poor and vulnerable.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to Mongolia for the Second Health Sector Development Project (HSDP2). 1  The report also 
describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for support for health reform, and if the Board 
approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will 
approve the TA.   
 
II.  RATIONALE:  SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Initial Reform Achievements 
 
2.  Mongolia has been reforming its health care system and health financing mechanisms 
since the early 1990s. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) through Health Sector Development 
Program (HSDP)2 has been helping the Government plan and implement sector reforms since 
1997 and has introduced significant and necessary changes in the health system. The aim is to 
replace  an  old  Soviet  model,  dominated  by  an  extensive  network  of  hospitals  that  were 
overstaffed, emphasized facility-based curative care, and not sustainable after transition, with 
one that is more responsive to client needs, based on primary health care (PHC) and preventive 
services, of good quality, and sustainable.  
 
3.  One of the major accomplishments under the HSDP was the introduction of family group 
practices (FGPs) to provide PHC. FGPs—teams of doctors and nurses—work as private entities 
through  contracts  with  local  administrations.  The  Government  established  237  FGPs  in 
Ulaanbaatar  and  in  all  aimag  centers  nationwide  by early 2002. FGPs  receive  capitation 
payment under performance-based contracts that incorporate incentives for FGPs to see the 
poor. The FGP system serves the poor and vulnerable better than other types of services3.  
 
4.  Other reforms included the introduction of licensing and accreditation. While licensing of 
FGPs has been established and applied nationwide, hospital accreditation has been applied 
only to a limited extent, reflecting weak reform in the hospital sector. Rationalization of hospitals 
and health personnel has reduced the number of beds and staff by 40% since 1990 (to 7.5 beds 
and 13.4 staff per 1,000 population in 2001). However, these ratios are still much higher than in 
comparable countries, and rationalization should be pursued. A review of the progress of HSDP 
implementation is in Appendix 2.   
 
B.  Key Problems and Opportunities  
 
5.  The health sector faces considerable challenges. The following key issues must be 
addressed to expand and sustain development progress in health:   
 
6.  Double Burden of Diseases. People’s health has improved steadily since 1996 but is 
still poor. The infant mortality rate (IMR) has declined but is still high at 30.2 per 1,000 live births 
in 20014 and is worse in rural than urban areas. The main causes of death among infants and

8.  Poor Rural Health Sector Development. The health system in rural areas is composed 
of bag feldshers (community nurses), soum health centers, and aimag hospitals. Bag feldshers 
and soum health centers provide PHC for  rural populations, including health education, and 
basic health services, including maternal services. Aimag hospitals (250–350 beds) provide 
first-referral services. For remote areas, inter-soum hospitals are set up as first-referral hospitals. 
Although providing PHC  to outpatients, soum health centers are  equipped with beds  mainly 
because of the centers' vast catchment areas and severe climate conditions.  
 
9.  Unequal access to quality health services, and  the worse  health status in rural than 
urban areas are serious constraints in the health sector. Health resources are concentrated in 
urban areas, particularly in Ulaanbaatar, while rural areas have a shortage of physicians and

3 
other  qualified  health  workers,  deteriorated  buildings, and a lack of basic equipment and 
supplies. Reflecting the low population density and low  service quality, soum health centers 
serve only 2–5 outpatients a day and 5-10 deliveries a year. Mortality rates are consistently 
higher in rural than urban areas, indicating  that rural Mongolians have not  benefited equally 
from health service improvement.  
 
10.  Human resources are scarce  in rural areas. Isolation, lack of opportunity for medical 
consultation with colleagues, limited practice due to the  small population, lack of up-to-date 
technical  material,  limited  opportunity  for  on-the-job training and continuing education with 
appropriate supervision, and difficult transportation and communication conditions are major 
obstacles to attracting and retaining qualified health staff in rural areas. Recently, the Ministry of 
Health (MOH) prepared a strategy to strengthen soum health centers, proposing to renovate 
and equip health centers, train and retain soum health workers, and pilot capitation payment at 
the  soum  level.  HSDP2  will  assist  this  MOH  initiative  and  provide  an integrated set of 
improvements.   
 
11.  Hospital-Dominated  System  and  Inefficient  Hospital  Management.  Hospital 
rationalization is still a major challenge. HSDP set an initial target of 7.5 hospital beds per 1,000 
population, which was met in 1999, but is still high for Mongolia’s economic level. Much of the 
health budget is spent keeping hospitals open and heated, depleting funds to finance care of 
patients. If hospitals are not further rationalized, investment impact will be diluted.   
 
12.  Rationalization  should  make  hospital  management  more  efficient.  Hospital  care is 
characterized by long stays (10.72 days) and relatively high admission rates (20.4% of  the 
population are hospitalized annually), leading to high bed occupancy. Long stays are driven by 
perverse funding  arrangements, low quality of services caused by  shortage of drugs and 
outdated treatment protocols, and facility-based protocols for infectious disease control, such as 
for tuberculosis. Many admissions are for pathologies that would be treated on an outpatient 
basis in international practice, such as headache, hypertension, and diabetes. Improvement in 
efficiency of hospital  management, including introduction of appropriate admission criteria, 
international standard treatment guidelines, and output based provider payment mechanisms, 
will reduce the required level of accommodation. The quality of PHC should be improved, and 
demand for it increased to reduce the need and demand for hospitals. 
 
13.  However, resistance is strong to reducing the number of beds and hospitals, not only 
among health personnel and MOH but also among  the people,  who are accustomed to the 
hospital-based  system.  MOH’s  previous  plans  to  close  or  merge  hospitals  have  been 
suspended due to protests from the people. External assistance has not been coordinated to 
facilitate rationalization. New hospitals are being built and the number of hospital beds has been 
increasing  in  Ulaanbaatar  since  2000.  Policy  dialogue  with  the  Government  needs  to  be 
renewed to pursue rationalization.   
 
14.  Poor Human Resources Development. The large-scale changes that have taken place 
in  clinical  and  managerial  arrangements  over  the  past  decade  have  created  many  new 
challenges for staff at all levels of the health system. Overstaffing and staff maldistribution have 
continued to hamper sector efficiency. The number of physicians has increased since 1999, 
particularly in Ulaanbaatar. The current high demand for physician training, and a lack of 
congruency between service needs and training intakes, has led to significant overproduction of 
physicians. Medical university students should be reduced, and incentives given to  physicians 
and nurses to stay in rural and remote areas.

4 
15.  Decentralization has become a  government priority. Provincial  governments became 
responsible  for  delivering  and  financing  health  services,  while  MOH  has  shifted  to  policy 
development, strategic planning, regulation and standard setting, and monitoring and evaluation. 
However, local governments lack experience, and planning and managerial capacity in resource 
allocation in the health sector. Some have diverted resources from health care to other sectors. 
Few have been able to follow MOH’s broad policy of shifting resources from hospitals to PHC. 
Despite  MOH’s  overall  responsibility  for  workforce  planning,  and  the  recently  developed 
National Health Workforce Plan 2002-2012, local governments continue to recruit, distribute, 
and train staff within the budget framework set by the Ministry of Finance and Economy (MOFE) 
in ways that may not always match MOH’s plan. If decentralization is to produce the expected 
positive outcomes, capacity of local governments must be built.     
 
16.  Since  2002,  the  environment  has  become  conducive  to  linking  policy  setting  with 
implementation as the Government has decided to delegate decision making in health budget 
allocation to MOH. However, data on health services, personnel, and budget are fragmented, 
and hardly linked with evidence-based decision making. Capacity building of MOH and local 
governments, combined with renewal of the health management information system (HMIS) and 
operational research, will have substantial positive impacts on sector efficiency.  
 
17.  Limited  and  Inefficient  Health  Care  Financing.5 Health  care  spending  is  low by 
international standards at 4.2% of gross domestic product (GDP). Thus, the Government must 
ensure that its  financial  allocations  are  fair  and  efficient,  and  that  spending is  prioritized 
according  to  health  needs.  However,  financial  management  knowledge  and  skills  are 
insufficient; and financing sources and fund flows and use are not understood enough to help 
authorities to make efficient and effective decisions. In 2003, the World Bank will help establish 
national health accounts to help the Government analyze health expenditures. 
 
18.  Mongolia  is  undergoing  major  public  sector  reform.  The  Public  Sector  Finance 
Management Law (PSFML) was passed by Parliament in 2002, and will be effective in 2003. 
Financial management capacity remains weak, and MOH lacks a comprehensive health sector 
finance policy and  an implementation plan.  Aimags lack the capacity to develop an efficient 
budget based on outputs. Training for health care finance at the central and aimag levels is, 
therefore, required.  
 
19.  Mongolia has supported the development of the social health insurance scheme since 
1994. The health insurance system provided universal compulsory coverage, and collected 
employer-employee contributions.  The Government subsidized premiums for those categorized 
as “vulnerable.” With the introduction of the new eligibility criteria in 2001, several people lost 
these  benefits,  as  compulsory  was  replaced  by  voluntary  coverage.  Further  assessments 
related to  the Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper in 2001  suggested that households were 
unable to pay premiums due to liquidity constraints or lack of geographical access, such as 
among the nomadic population, and herdsman. 
 
20.  The sources of health care financing in 2001 included government budget (74%), Health 
Insurance Fund (HIF) (23%), and cost sharing (3%). According to PSFML, HIF is expected to 
contribute up to 32% of the total health budget by 2003. The Government expects HIF to 
improve its income from premiums, as fewer people  are now categorized under “voluntary” 
coverage  and  eligible  for  exemptions  on  premiums.  However,  recent  premium  collection 
indicates that HIF revenue may not improve quickly and that the Government may thus remain

21.  People’s Perceptions and Attitudes to Health Reform.6 HSDP identified people’s 
traditional perceptions of and attitudes to health services—valuing hospital-based curative care, 
for instance—as a major risk. HSDP aimed to reform the system to emphasize PHC. HSDP 
strategies included information and education campaigns as well as quality assurance of FGPs, 
which  provide  PHC  to  the  urban  population.  Increased  utilization  of  FGPs  and  patient 
satisfaction with them  were  observed.  However, many people, particularly in Ulaanbaatar, 
continue to visit hospitals, bypassing FGPs: 50% of hospital outpatients have gone directly to 
hospitals.  
 
22.  The information and education campaign supported by HSDP was found to be effective 
in promoting reform and emphasizing the role of FGPs. The campaign was particularly effective 
in  the  early  stages  but  gradually  tapered  off  as  budgets  were  reduced.  Information 
dissemination  was  largely  undertaken  by  project  staff  as  MOH  and  local  government 
involvement was not optimal.  Information and education are important components of the 
overall reform agenda and need to have a high priority during all phases of  HSDP2. Local 
governments and staff must lead  information campaigns, with  coordination and advice  from 
MOH.  
 
23.  HSDP helped the  FGP system improve service quality by  (i) introducing a capitation 
payment and performance-based contract, (ii) applying licensing for FGP quality assurance, (iii) 
providing  training  and  equipment,  and  (iv)  establishing  a  good  working  environment  by 
rehabilitating and rebuilding facilities. However, training consisted of only one short course and 
was not followed by supervision or on-the-job advice. Similarly, training impacts were not 
analyzed. Surveys thus reported limited knowledge and practice of standard  protocols. The 
population must have confidence in FGP and PHC to reduce dependency on hospitals. Quality 
is a major factor in raising confidence. HSDP2 thus emphasizes improving the service quality of 
FGPs and soum health centers and will provide a comprehensive package of training courses, 
on-the-job advice, and systematic impact assessments. These components will be further 
supplemented by continuing education.   
 
24.  Lack  of  Harmonized  International  Assistance  and  Its  Limited  Utilization. 
International assistance for the public health sector, after peaking in 1994, has since declined in 
absolute size and in share of public health expenditure, which declined to 12% in 2000 from 
32% in 1994. Appendix 3 provides details of recent health sector investments. The purposes 
and  priorities  of  various  funding  agencies  are  not  always  consistent  with  those  of  the 
Government.  For  instance,  external  investment  in  specialized  hospitals  and  advanced 
equipment could divert or even distort Government’s spending priorities in the heath sector if not 
carefully planned. Inputs are sometimes duplicated. Strategies and approaches used in external 
assistance are not necessarily compatible with each other, thus confusing local governments 
and communities involved in donor programs.  
 
25.  Many examples of suboptimal use of donor assistance can be cited. The World Health 
Organization (WHO) has highlighted that goods and services provided by donors are often left 
unused or underutilized. WHO also observed that too many consultants cover the same areas 
and produce too many reports for MOH to digest, leading to unutilized consultant inputs. Impact

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Goal and Objectives 
 
26.  HSDP2’s goal is to improve the health of people, especially the poor and vulnerable, 
such as women and children in target areas. HSDP2 has two objectives:  
 
(i)  Improve quality and utilization of health services in rural areas, especially for the 
poor and vulnerable. 
 
(ii)  Build  the  institutional  capacity  of  the  health  sector,  based  on  the  reform 
achievements  and  institutional  developments  of  HSDP  in  sector  efficiency, 
effectiveness, and sustainability.  
 
B.  Components and Outputs  
 
27.  HSDP2 has three components, which were designed through intensive national and 
local  consultations  with  key  stakeholders,  paying  attention  to  the  needs  of  the  poor  and 
vulnerable:  (i)  integrated  improvement  of  rural  health  services,  (ii)  institutional  capacity 
development, and (iii) project management.  
 
28.  Components (ii) and (iii) will  have an impact  nationwide, while component (i) will be 
implemented in five rural aimags (Bayanhongor, Dornod, Dzavhan, Ovorhangay, and Hentiy), 
which were selected for their level and severity of poverty, level of infant and maternal mortality, 
and incidence of infectious diseases. The profiles of the HSDP2 aimags are in Appendix 4. 
HSDP2 will invest in areas that will have the greatest impact on the poor, women, and children.   
 
1.  Integrated Improvement of Rural Health Services 
 
29.  This component focuses on improving access to, utilization of, and quality of basic PHC 
services in an integrated way in the HSDP2 aimags. Investments will be made at the bag, soum, 
and  aimag  levels.  Factors  and  challenges  affecting  service  quality  and  utilization  will  be 
comprehensively addressed by (i) improving working conditions by rehabilitating facilities and 
providing equipment; (ii) upgrading knowledge and skills of staff; (iii) providing incentives to staff 
to work in rural areas, and  meet the needs of  the poor and vulnerable;  and (iv) providing 
participatory and informative public heath campaigns to create demand for quality PHC services, 
and improve community, and family health and nutrition practices.  
 
30.  Basic health  services strengthened under this component include maternal and child 
health (MCH) services and infectious disease control, which contribute to reaching MDGs and 
providing cost-effective health services to combat prevalent diseases. The scope of these 
services,7 in line with life-cycle approach, includes immunization; growth monitoring; school

motherhood (antenatal care, delivery, and postnatal care); basic neonatal care; breastfeeding; 
tuberculosis control; sexually transmitted infection control; water-borne disease control; and 
prevention of noncommunicable diseases, particularly coronary heart diseases, hypertension, 
and diabetes,  which are related to inappropriate diet  and smoking. Nutrition support should 
always be a part of an integrated approach. HSDP2 will help all health workers provide these 
services effectively, in accordance with health workers’ terms of reference.  
 
31.  Funds for recurrent operating and maintenance costs must be available to make optimal 
use  of  capital  investments.  The  Government’s  support  for  training  and  public  information 
campaigns must be secured. Incremental financial requirements associated with HSDP2 will be 
assessed annually and included in the aimag health budget plan.   
 
a.  Soum Health Service Development 
32.  A capitation payment system linked with performance-based contracts will be introduced 
at rehabilitated or rebuilt soum health centers and then rolled out to the remainder of HSDP2 
aimags. The purpose of the capitation system incentives is to promote efficient management by 
service providers; improve quality performance,  especially in essential health services; and 
increase responsiveness to the needs of the poor. Capitation rates, performance indicators, and 
monitoring methods will follow FGP mechanisms but adjusted to rural needs, delivery care, and 
inpatient needs. An international consultant will  help HSDP2 aimag health departments and 
soum health centers make a detailed action plan to implement a capitation system and establish 
monitoring mechanisms. A series of workshops and meetings is planned.    
 
33.  Around 13 soum health centers will be upgraded and around 10 soum health centers 
rebuilt where they are. The requirements for civil works for soum health centers will be met by 
adopting a flexible approach, which  will reflect the services provided (basic clinical services, 
preventive services, and health  education and health promotion); actual utilization; and other 
requirements such as staff  residences and community rooms  as incentives to rural health 
workers. Energy-efficient design with appropriate technical services such as telephones, heating, 
water, sanitation, and waste management will be provided. Renewable energy measures will be 
adopted. Downsizing of facilities and adoption of energy-efficiency measures are expected to 
substantially reduce running cost,  particularly heating,  which accounts for 40–60% of costs. 
Maintenance requirements will be identified, a plan developed,  and financial arrangements 
agreed on before work commences. During the first year, a civil works survey will be undertaken 
to  assess  these  points,  make  an  inventory,  and  develop  designs.  An  environmental 
management plan will be prepared, together with monitoring systems.  Health center  boards, 
which will be set up to promote community participation in health center management, will be 
involved in designing the health centers.   
 
34.  Based on the agreed-on role of soum health centers and the need to provide essential 
services, a set of basic equipment will be provided to all soum health centers in HSDP2 aimags. 
The equipment at this level will be similar to that of FGPs and outreach kits of FGP doctors but 
adjusted to rural and obstetric needs as well as for environmental management.     
 
35.  Information and communication technology (ICT) services will be provided at the soum 
and aimag levels to (i) improve office function and administration, (ii) strengthen HMIS, and (iii) 
support distance learning. HMIS at the soum level will focus on collecting and analyzing data on 
health status and service utilization, and on improving services delivery. HMIS is expected to 
record epidemiological and activity data at source and prepare electronic patient records. For

8 
distance learning, this component will provide electronic access to health documents, up-to-date 
protocols and initiatives [initially through compact disc read-only memory (CD-ROM) and then 
through network]. Soum health centers will be connected through e-mail for online consultations 
with HSDP2 aimag hospitals. CD-ROMs, to be developed by the MOH Directorate for Medical 
Services  (DMS),  will  supplement  distance  learning.  An  international  training  specialist  will 
prepare a distance-learning plan; develop concepts, training curricula, and training materials for 
distance learning; and establish a health library.  
 
36.  Due to poor electricity and telephone  infrastructure, limited budget for operational costs, 
and health workers’  limited ICT experience,  careful and phased approaches are required to 
ensure the success of ICT support. International consultants will  help HSDP2 aimag health 
departments assess infrastructure status and operational costs and develop  a phased  ICT 
action plan (system, software, supply, and training). Training will be provided.  
 
37.  Soum health center staff will receive training. Senior staff  will receive training  in the 
basics of management. Efficient management is especially important to implement a capitation 
payment mechanism. This training will be organized centrally by  DMS, but will be delivered 
locally through outreach branches.  
 
38.  Bag  feldshers  will  be  trained  to  improve  public  health  knowledge  and  skills  in 
accordance with their job description, and, where necessary, provided with basic equipment. In 
particular, feldshers in remote bags will receive motorbikes to increase their outreach range. 
Particular attention will be given to (i) health education and promotion; (ii) routine health check-
ups and consultation, and preventive and public health service in MCH and nutrition; and (iii) 
collection and analysis of data for HMIS. MCH kits have been distributed to all bag feldshers by 
other agencies, and HSDP2 will help feldshers use these kits more efficiently and enhance the 
impacts of feldshers’ activities.    
 
39.  Bag feldshers, with the assistance of soum and aimag staff, will intensively and regularly 
organize a wide range of health education and promotion campaigns to improve community and 
family health and nutrition practices and raise public awareness of HSDP2 goals and scope. 
Health education materials and equipment will be provided to bags and soums.  Campaign 
impact will be assessed and best performance rewarded. The campaign budget will cover 
professional  technical  support,  material  supplies,  operational  and  logistical  costs,  and 
performance incentives. Feldshers will prepare an annual campaign plan in close consultation 
with soums and communities.   
 
b.  Referral System Support 
40.  Inter-soum and aimag hospitals will be strengthened as the first-referral system for 
targeted essential services, particularly MCH services in HSDP2 aimags. Five inter-soum and 
five aimag  hospitals will be upgraded and  equipped. The list of equipment follows the first-
referral units provided under HSDP, but will be adjusted to meet rural needs. Clinical and 
managerial training will be provided to improve quality of referral services.   
 
41.  Assistance  will  be  provided  to  rehabilitated  facilities  at  the  soum,  inter-soum,  and 
HSDP2 aimag levels in environmental management. A monitoring system will be also set up. 
HSDP2 will procure medical waste containers at rehabilitated/rebuilt soum health centers and 
cover the cost of transporting collected medical waste to aimag hospitals for disposal. A cost-
effective incinerator will be procured and installed at each HSDP2 aimag hospital. Detailed 
medical waste management guidelines will be developed and training organized.

2.  Institutional Capacity Development  
 
42.  HSDP initiated a reform process that defined the direction, and provided the basis for, 
health sector development. To develop the health sector and improve sector efficiency, equity, 
quality,  and  sustainability,  ongoing  reforms  must  be  consolidated  and  sector  capacity 
strengthened to plan, manage, coordinate, and monitor system development.    
 
a.  Consolidation of Reform in System Development  
 
43.  HSDP supported the shift to PHC, quality assurance, and sector rationalization (hospital 
and overstaffing), which were major reforms. HSDP2 will continue to pursue and accelerate 
them, which is indispensable to develop an efficient, effective, and pro-poor health sector.  
 
44.  The shift to PHC has resulted in the establishment of FGPs in urban areas nationwide. 
Utilization  of  and  users’  satisfaction  with  FGPs  has  been  increasing,  but  strong  support 
continues to be required until FGP is firmly rooted. HSDP2 will improve service quality and FGP 
performance by reviewing FGPs’ performance and identifying  training needs, especially in 
management and finance, and outreach services to the poor, women, children, disabled, and 
underserved. Based on identified training needs, all FGPs will be retrained and 50 new doctors 
trained annually in family medicine. Training will be linked with MDGs and prevalent diseases. 
Equipment will be provided to improve quality.  Monitoring of service  quality, management, 
service  utilization,  affordability,  and  satisfaction  among  the  vulnerable  groups  will  be 
strengthened. HSDP2 will renew advocacy for PHC.   
 
45.  Quality  assurance  will  be  enhanced  by  strengthening  licensing  and  accreditation 
mechanisms. Three years have passed since the licensing system of medical doctors, FGPs, 
and other major health workers was established and implemented. HSDP2 will assess licensing 
system’s performance and propose mechanisms for greater quality assurance impact. Recent 
amendments in health insurance legislation require all hospitals to become accredited. HSDP2 
will review and modify the accreditation system to make it not only a stronger quality assurance 
tool but also a more effective management tool. The quality control structures and functions of 
MOH and DMS will be reviewed. Relevant government staff will be trained. HSDP2 will reinforce 
quality  assurance  mechanisms  by  improving  purchaser  and  provider  organizations  and 
supporting professional associations.  
 
46.   A critical step for hospital rationalization is efficient hospital inpatient management 
leading to a lower accommodation capacity requirement. HSDP2 will review admission policies 
and inpatient management practices, prepare guidelines on inpatient management, and train 
hospital managers. HSDP2 will assess bed requirements in line with actual utilization rates and 
improved  management,  and  propose  appropriate  hospital  capacity.  HSDP2  will  also help 
improve inpatient management and rationalization of beds at hospitals, as pilots, where modern 
treatment protocols are introduced or where modern equipment is provided by the Government 
or donors.  
 
47.  HSDP2  will  help  the  Government rationalize staff by developing and implementing 
career development support schemes to train those who wish to move to rural areas or leave 
the public health sector. A career development support unit (CDSU) will be established in DMS 
to provide counseling, training, and social marketing to increase job opportunities for scheme 
participants. Posts vacated by participants will not be refilled.

b.  Capacity Building   
 
48.  HSDP2  will  strengthen  institutional  capacity  in  planning,  budgeting,  staffing, 
management, evaluation, and coordination at the national, aimag and soum levels. HMIS and 
operational researches will be reinforced as management tools. At the national level, support 
will be given to MOH, including DMS, in undertaking sector reform and development. Critical to 
the success of HSDP2 is the enhancement of the role of DMS, which will need to take the lead 
in capacity building for the health sector. Under the restructuring of the public health sector, the 
Government has decided to convert DMS to an agency under MOH. DMS will become the 
implementation arm of MOH in improving health care services while MOH will concentrate on 
policy/strategy development, regulation, and coordination. Training activities will be planned by 
DMS and delivered in close collaboration with other technical institutions. MOH will coordinate 
training to avoid duplication with other international agencies. 
 
49.  For training under the component for integrated improvement in rural health services, 
DMS will develop, with the assistance of international consultants, a rural training plan for health 
workers in HSDP2 aimags. To strengthen decentralized training activities, outreach DMS offices 
will be set up and equipped in two HSDP2 aimags.   
 
50.  A series of nationwide training courses are also envisaged under HSDP2, including 
training for (i) management  and planning; (ii) human resource development; (iii)  health care 
financing, health economics, and policies; (iv) accreditation and quality assurance; and (v) 
clinical areas. HSDP2 will first train trainers at the national level to prepare and monitor health 
management courses and develop guidelines and material. Aimag and soum health managers 
will be trained in planning, budgeting, managing, and monitoring health services.  
 
51.  To build institutional capacity in human resource development, HSDP2 will review the 
human resource development policy and regulations and project staffing needs for 2004–2007. 
Based on this policy, HSDP2 will help MOH develop a workforce plan, covering the number, 
profiles, geographical, and professional distribution and job description of human resources, and 
training needs. The plan will include specific measures to reduce turnover of health workers. 
HSDP2 will provide training and studies to build skills and capacities to plan and monitor a 
performance-based  salary  scheme,  which  the  Government  plans  to  introduce.  Preservice 
training of students from rural areas and those who can  serve underserved areas  will help 
allocate  more  qualified  staff  to  rural  areas.  Continuing  education  plans,  curriculums,  and 
learning material will be developed.  
 
52.  To strengthen client responsiveness and participation of the health sector, HSDP2 will 
encourage the development of general information material for patients and clients on health 
service, education, and promotion. HSDP2 will develop and implement the concepts of patients’ 
rights and responsibilities, with a focus on the requirements of the poor and vulnerable groups. 
Complaint  procedures  will  be  reviewed  and  mechanisms  developed  to  address  clients’ 
complaints in a fair and equitable manner.  
 
53.  HSDP2 will develop MOH capacity and mechanisms to coordinate donor assistance and 
promote  its  optimal  use.  HSDP2  will  help  MOH  engage  donors  in  strategy  and  action 
formulation, consolidate  donor assistance to shared goals and strategies, and maintain a 
monitoring and policy dialogue. For optimal use of donor assistance, HSDP2 will help MOH 
prepare donor guidelines and set up a  functional structure to advise donors, review their 
proposals,  and  propose  safeguards.  HSDP2  will  enable  MOH  to  create  an  environment 
conducive to effective donor assistance and to mobilizing further donor assistance.

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Project Benefits and Beneficiaries 
 
66.  The outcome of HSDP2 should be an improvement in the health status of the population 
in general, and in the  rural HSDP2 aimags in particular.  The project will benefit the whole 
population indirectly through nationwide components that support sector reform and institution 
building.  
 
67.  HSDP2 will focus on improving rural health services. Under the targeted rural health 
service component, where  most HSDP2 funds are allocated, about 400,000 people in rural 
HSDP2 aimags, representing 18% of the total population, will benefit directly from improved 
availability and quality of rural health services.   
 
68.  HSDP2 will strengthen public health education and preventive works at the bag level, 
renovate and equip soum health centers and aimag hospitals, train all health system staff to 
improve service delivery, and set up incentives in provider payment arrangements to increase 
attention to the poor. HSDP2 will encourage greater participation of stakeholders. HSDP2 will 
support decentralization. Transparent and accountable management with well-trained managers 
will ensure the delivery of quality service to  the poor and vulnerable, including women and 
children. Most users of PHC are women and children. Most health providers are women in rural 
areas. Women will thus benefit directly from HSDP2.  
 
69.  HSDP2  will  (i)  enhance  health  care  institutional  and  individual  capacities  through 
studies, training, and development activities; (ii) support improvement of the policy capability of 
MOH; (iii) help DMS take a stronger lead in developing institutional capacities throughout the 
health sector; (iv) help HIF of SSIGO and its local offices develop their roles and responsibilities; 
(v) train managers and staff at the aimag and soum levels; (vi) support professional associations 
in expanding and deepening reforms; and (vii) strengthen client responsiveness.     
 
B.  Risks 
 
70.  The Government is introducing reforms and changes in public sector management and 
financing systems. However, if initiatives are not  accompanied by a corresponding change in 
the capacity and capability of stakeholders or by an efficient monitoring and evaluation system, 
expected outcomes are not likely to be produced. This risk will be minimized in HSDP2 through 
strong capacity-building support, provision of technical services, and strengthened monitoring 
systems.  
 
71.  Reforms require a change in attitude of staff and clients, and the recognition of the need

73.  HSDP2 will rehabilitate and rebuild hospitals/health centers in the five HSDP2 aimags.

D.  Social Analysis 
 
74.  HSDP2 focuses on poverty and gender and aims to focus on the health of the rural poor. 
HSDP2 will invest in five aimags, where 48.5% of the people are poor. Appendix 4 provides 
details  on  selected  aimags,  and  Appendix  13  provides  the  poverty  and  gender  analysis, 
including the gender plan, and other social analyses. 
 
75.  HSDP2 reviewed ethnic differentials in health and social outcomes.  Although Mongolia 
comprises over 16 distinct clans and ethnic groups, none is  so distinct from  the dominant 
society as to be especially disadvantaged in the development process. Therefore, HSDP2 is 
classified as category C in terms of indigenous peoples. However, to facilitate understanding 
and acceptance of HSDP2 among ethnic minorities, languages familiar to ethnic minorities will 
be used in information campaigns and local training.  
 
76.  The population overall has good access to health services, but disparities are evident by 
income and locations. Health service utilization among the poor is far lower than among the 
wealthy.8 The poor are also more likely to visit soum health centers, primarily because of access 
and costs of care, while higher-income households are more likely to use aimag and private 
hospitals.9 The quality of health services is poorer in rural than urban areas. HSDP2 will, 
therefore, concentrate on upgrading rural health services and facilitate incentives to attract 
health workers to underserved areas.

77.  Rural PHC is provided by bag feldshers in communities and by soum health centers.

E.  Economic Analysis10 
 
1.  Economic Benefits 
 
78.  Investment  under  HSDP2  is  expected  to  yield  substantial  economic,  social,  and 
institutional  benefits.  The  major  benefits  from  HSDP2  are  out-of-pocket  savings,  and 
productivity gains as more resources are channeled to rural health. HSDP2 will have several 
positive health and welfare impacts that can be quantified in economic terms. HSDP2 is 
expected to increase the number of persons receiving quality health care and will contribute 
directly to improve the productivity of target beneficiaries. Even with relatively conservative 
assumptions, HSDP2 yields an economic internal rate of return of 24.4%. The real rate of return 
is likely to be higher as healthy workers are able to work more productively and earn more than 
unhealthy workers. These benefits exclude externalities that accrue to HSDP2.    
 
2.  Fiscal Impact 
 
79.  HSDP2 has been designed to minimize recurrent cost implications. The improvement of 
the health service delivery system is intended to reduce wastage, improve the internal efficiency 
of health service delivery, improve energy efficiency of health facilities, thus reducing the cost of 
health care for the individual and society. The incremental recurrent costs of HSDP2 arise 
largely from increased access to quality health care. Although new construction and renovation 
of health facilities are financed by ADB proceeds, local governments must operate and maintain 
the premises to ensure sustainability. HSDP invests in PHC that is internationally proven cost-
effective services that, together with minimized recurrent cost, will increase sustainability.      
 
80.  The financial sustainability analysis evaluates the impact of HSDP2 on the government 
budget. From the total project cost of $17.5 million, the Government will finance about $3.5 
million of the total project cost. The Government’s annual share in project costs will average 
$680,000, or 1.1% of the health sector annual budget of $53.9 million. Recurrent costs to be 
borne by the Government during HSDP2 are estimated at $590,000 per year. The budgetary 
impact of the estimated annual recurrent costs during and after HSDP2 implementation is 
considered manageable.

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR SUPPORT FOR HEALTH SECTOR REFORM 
 
A.  Background And Rationale 
 
1.  The Ministry of Health (MOH) developed a national health policy in 1997, but it was not 
formally ratified by Parliament. The  public health policy and other national health programs, 
including  the  Soum  Health  Development  Program,  have  been  endorsed  and  provide  a 
framework for strategic development of the health sector. However, in view of rapid change in 
the  environment,  MOH  needs to review the continued applicability of some programs and 
develop policies, particularly those related to health financing and government-wide financial 
reforms, to ensure a comprehensive and coherent health sector strategy.   
 
2.  The Public Sector Finance Management Law (PSFML) was approved in 2002 and is to 
be effective from 2003. The Government expects to move rapidly from conventional input- to 
output-based budgeting. Since PSFML requires public agencies (including hospitals) to be 
funded based on their outputs or products, the outputs that hospital and health services provide 
need to be defined and their costs estimated. This process will help identify population needs, 
assess budget needs to address these concerns, and target resources to areas with the 
greatest need and with the greatest inequity in health outcomes. In the health sector, PSFML 
would give MOH more control over the budget process and the use of funds to meet overall 
sector  objectives.  PSFML  shifts  the  responsibility  for  health  care  budget  planning  and 
administration from the Ministry of Finance and Economy (MOFE) in Ulaanbaatar and aimag 
governors’ offices to MOH central and aimag offices. The PSFML will ensure appropriate 
allocation for health care at the aimag level. The new process can help streamline the health 
system, leading to rationalized services and better-targeted interventions. 
 
3.  MOH will have to prepare to administer and monitor reforms, staff will require training in 
management and output-based budgeting, activity and service costs will need estimation based 
on output/performance, and performance indicators will need to be identified. MOH lacks staff 
and the skills mix to address this challenge. Staff should be trained and deployed  for these 
functions, and the skills mix and capacity strengthened, at the central and aimag levels, to 
ensure proper training, administration, and monitoring of the new financial and management 
systems. 
 
4.  The  role  of  the  Health  Insurance  Fund  (HIF)  in  supporting  public  sector  health 
expenditures and complementing government budgetary allocations is expected to increase 
significantly. In 2002, the sources of health care financing were government budget (74%), HIF 
(23%), and cost sharing by patients (3%). Services covered under HIF include inpatient  and 
outpatient care, and drugs. HIF was established in 1994 and is administered by the State Social 
Insurance General Office (SSIGO) in the Ministry of Social Welfare and Labor (MSWL). Health 
policy and regulations are developed under MOH direction, but health insurance implementation 
and management are under MSWL’s direction. The evolving roles and functions of HIF should 
be made clear, and the links between  health policy and health insurance implementation 
strengthened. 
 
5.  HIF aims at universal coverage through a combination of compulsory, voluntary, and 
employer-employee contributions. Almost 70% of HIF income is from compulsory employer-paid 
premiums. Voluntary contributions were abolished recently and those identified under social 
assistance programs are eligible to receive government subsidies. However, the impact of these 
reforms on the vulnerable, underserved, and poor is unclear. Recent evidence suggests that a

coverage, with some groups more affected than others either due to adverse selection or 
liquidity constraints. People’s health could be adversely affected if quality basic health care is 
not easily accessible and affordable. The system suffers from moral hazard, as appropriate 
regulations and criteria on service use (e.g., hospital admission criteria, length of hospital stay,

17.  The Ministry of Health (MOH) has regulations on collection, transportation, and disposal

regulations, mainly due to lack of local budget and, therefore, insufficient waste containers,

A.  Poverty and Gender Analysis 
 
1.  The Second Health Sector Development Project (HSDP2) has a poverty and gender 
focus and addresses  health concerns of the rural poor and women, such as infectious and 
communicable diseases and reproductive health. HSDP2 will cover five rural aimags with higher 
poverty incidence and worse health outcomes than others: Bayanhongor, Dzavhan, Dornod, 
Hentiy, and  Ovorhangay. Poverty, health, and gender considerations justify the selection of 
HSDP2 sites. This section provides an overview of absolute and relative poverty and health 
conditions over time. 
 
2.  Poverty incidence increased from 15% in 19901 to 36% in 1995.2 Absolute poverty has 
stabilized overall since 1995, except in the aimag centers (not including Ulaanbaatar), where 
poverty  incidence  increased  due  to  internal  migration  and  growing  unemployment.  The 
population living in extreme poverty increased from 1995 to 1998. Poverty is growing. Urs aimag 
has the largest population living below poverty, and Dzavhan, the largest population living in 
extreme  poverty.  More  female- than male-headed households live in poverty. Ovorhangay 
aimag has the largest proportion of herdsmen.   
 
3.  The increasing differential in income translates into an increasing differential in the 
population’s ability to afford health care. Per capita monthly health expenditure is seven times 
greater among wealthier  than poorer households. The share of household expenditure for 
health among the poor (2.3%) is  substantially larger than  that of the wealthier households 
(1.5%). Several other indirect costs of health are unmeasurable, such as travel cost to health 
facilities, opportunity cost of time, and drug costs. Many rural health facilities are perceived to 
offer relatively poor quality of care and so patients travel as far as aimag centers and sometimes 
to Ulaanbaatar to attend hospitals. Health insurance subsidies are offered to those defined as 
“vulnerable,” but the income- or food-poor and the unemployed are less likely to be categorized 
as “vulnerable” under the current definition. 
 
4.  The infant mortality rate (IMR) was 64 per 1,000 live births in 2000 (MICS 2000).  MOH 
data suggest that IMR declined from 64 in 1990 to 35 by 2000, but almost 50% of infant deaths 
are suspected to have been missed through incomplete demographic registration. Rural IMR is 
1.5 times higher than urban IMR, and Dornod aimag has an IMR double that of Dundgobi (which 
has the lowest IMR). IMR for boys is higher than for girls. 
 
5.  MMR increased to 161 per 100,000 live births in 1996–1998 from 119 in 1990 (Maternal

concern. At least 60% of deliveries with complications at aimag hospitals were referred from 
soum health centers, primarily due to eclampsia.

Secondary  stakeholders  consisted  of  national  and  local  policy  and  decision  makers.  The 
analysis of response showed a high degree of concurrence among stakeholders on the causes 
and effects of problems in delivering good-quality and affordable health services, especially to 
the poor and vulnerable. The main divergence was in perceptions of how the poorest groups are 
treated, with staff having a much better opinion of their interventions than the recipients, who 
clearly feel discriminated against by individuals and the system. 
 
  The  differences  among  stakeholder  groups  required  a  wide  range  of  participation 
strategies. For service users and service providers,  the participatory appraisal and planning 
method was used. For local and national policy- and decision makers, one-on-one interviews, 
group interviews, and  regional workshops were conducted. To deepen participation, project 
component  design  was  done  through  counterpart  groups  in  MOH  and  a  multidisciplinary 
steering committee (MOH, Ministry of Education, Ministry of Finance and Economy, Parliament, 
State Social  Insurance  General  Office, university and aimag representatives).  Widespread 
participatory discussions took place, particularly to identify needs and demands for capacity-
building activities to implement reform.    
 
            Participation input proved to be useful and important to project design, not only because 
of  the  information  provided  but  also  because  of  the  resulting  awareness  of  the  value  of 
participation and consultation. The consultation loop set up with stakeholders will be maintained.

C.  Gender Plan 
 
10.  Women in Mongolia live longer and are healthier than men. Life expectancy at birth in 
2001 is 61.2 years for men and 68.3 years for women. In terms of healthy life expectancy, which 
takes into consideration disability in addition to length of life, women have 58.0 years of healthy

11.  However, these better indicators  do not  necessarily mean that women receive better 
social and health attention. Maternal mortality, which is largely preventable by the application of 
available medical knowledge and basic technologies, is unacceptably high and does not show 
any improvement over years. It may even be worsening. Women suffer from an unnecessary 
disease  burden.  Reproductive  health  conditions  are  the  cumulative  result  of  poverty;

2.  HSDP2 aims to focus on health concerns of the rural poor, such as infectious and

elsewhere in Mongolia, inpatient admission is about 20%. The average visits/person/year in

hospitals (98%). HSDP2 therefore aims to provide access and quality at primary health care

B.  Benefit Assumptions 
 
3.  HSDP2 will have several positive impacts on the population’s health and welfare that 
can be quantified in economic terms. HSDP2 is expected to increase the number of persons 
receiving quality health care and will contribute directly to improving the productivity  of target 
beneficiaries. The strengthening of these facilities will have an important health and social 
impact in revitalizing the aimag and soum centers. Economic benefits will potentially include 
high social returns from the investment through (i) resource cost savings and (ii) productivity 
benefits from target beneficiaries.   
 
4.  Cost savings consist of a reduction in private out-of-pocket expenses for health care as 
a result of (i) increased access to rural health services to reduce transport cost; (ii) improved 
health service delivery to reduce cost of treatment from public preventive health care in lieu of 
private consultation/treatment; and (iii) reforms in health financing to reduce cost of health 
services, especially the poor. 
 
5.  Productivity gains are the result of less time lost to illness, and increase in productivity of 
adults and children. Improving people’s health will lead to fewer days lost from illness without 
the health interventions improved by HSDP2. The base case assumes that benefits will accrue 
to  improved  productivity  due  to  efficient  treatment  and  easily  available  services.  In  the 
calculation of benefits, the target population in the five aimags was used to calculate the number 
of patients that will benefit from HSDP2. The annual number of patients who will incur cost 
savings and productivity gains is based on the difference between health incidence with and 
without HSDP2. The following describe the assumptions in more detail.  
 
6.  Cost Savings.   These are the annual benefits expected as a result of savings from 
average out-of-pocket expenses expected to be incurred had the patient been treated at a 
private hospital rather than at a public health center. Benefits are calculated based on $100 
annual incremental costs that a patient will incur to go to a private facility, assuming four visits 
per year, at $25 savings per visit on transport and co-payments. The number of patients who 
visit PHC facilities covered by HSDP2 are estimated based on the population of each aimag, 
times the health incidence related to infectious diseases. The average number of infectious 
diseases (per 10,000 people) ranged from about 68 (Ovorhangay) to 225 (Dornod) (1996–
2000). The number of patients is equal to the aimag population times the number of infectious 
disease/10,000 people times number of outpatient visits per year.   
 
7.  Productivity. This is the expected benefit from increased earnings or inflows and is 
quantified based on the following:

C.  Fiscal Impact 
 
10.  Mongolia made impressive gains in macroeconomic adjustment in the early transition 
years. However, during recent years, average growth rate has dropped and high unemployment 
continued. The growth in national income declined to 1.1% in 1990–2000. Mongolia’s per capita 
gross domestic product (GDP) declined to $390 in 2001. Poverty remains high, and 36% of the 
population lives below the poverty line. 
 
11.  The declining economy has translated into a weakening public sector resource base for 
health. The transition to a market economy has resulted in a decline in public health expenditure 
as a percentage of GDP, from 5.4% in 1990 to 4.2% in 2000. Total public sector health 
expenditure was $39.5 million equivalent or only $17 per capita in 2000. This amounts to about 
4.2% of GDP, or about 10.5% of total government expenditures. In real terms, the share and 
amount for health have declined in the past decade but trends in recent years have indicated 
increased spending in the health sector. Despite this, the 2003 health budget reflects long 
standing weaknesses in the health sector, including an oversized tertiary sector, high utility 
costs, and inadequate capital investment. The budget also represents changes consistent with 
the new sector strategies, including greater investment in rural health service, and expanding 
role for health insurance and greater involvement of the private sector.  
 
12.  HSDP2 will address these weaknesses and support the proposed reforms. HSDP2 has 
been designed to minimize recurrent cost implications for the Government. The improvement of

58  Appendix 14 
health service delivery systems under HSDP2 is intended to reduce wastage, improve the 
internal efficiency of health service delivery, thus reducing the cost of health care for the 
individual and society. The incremental recurrent costs of HSDP2 arise largely from increased 
access to quality health care. Although new construction and renovation of health facilities are 
being  financed,  sustainability  is  being  ensured  by  the  prior  commitment  of  the  local 
governments to operate and maintain the premises.  FGP recurrent costs are expected to be 
financed through the health insurance fund and have, since 2000, comprised about 9% of public 
health expenditure.   
 
13.  The financial sustainability analysis evaluates the impact of HSDP2 on the government 
budget. The total financial cost of HSDP2, inclusive of taxes, duties, contingencies, and interest 
charges, is $17.5 million for around 5 years. The Government’s annual share in HSDP2 costs 
will average around $680,000 equivalent, or about 1.1% of the health sector average annual 
budget of about $53.9 million annually. The recurrent costs to be borne by the Government 
during HSDP2 are estimated to be about $590,000 million per year and include (i) the operating 
expenses of the project implementation unit, and Directorate for Medical Services; and (ii) 
operational, maintenance, and replacement costs of new and renovated health facilities and 
equipment under HSDP2. FGPs under HSDP2 will continue to be funded by the Government 
during  and  after  HSDP2  implementation.  The  budgetary  impact  of  the  estimated  annual 
recurrent costs during and after HSDP2 implementation is considered minimal.
